The initial filing contained errors dates officers directors signed Form 10-K dates certifications attached exhibits Form 10-K.&#160; This filing consists entire annual report initially filed dates documents executed relevant individuals.</font></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We modified updated filing disclosures set original Form 10-K.&#160; Accordingly, Form 10-K/A reflect events occurring filing initial Form 10-K modify update disclosures.</font></p> <p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:center;"><b><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">PART I</font></u></b></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Certain statements contained Form 10-K, including limitation, statements words &#147;believes,&#148; &#147;estimates,&#148; &#147;expects&#148; words similar import, constitute &#147;forward statements&#148; meaning Section 27A Securities Act 1933 Section 21E Securities Exchange Act 1934.&#160; Such words expressions intended identify forward statements, intended constitute exclusive means identifying statements.&#160; Such forward statements involve unknown risks, uncertainties factors actual results, performance achievements Company, industry results, materially future results, performance achievements expressed implied forward statements.&#160; Given uncertainties, prospective investors cautioned place undue reliance forward statements.&#160; The Company disclaims obligation update factors publicly announce results revisions forward statements contained reflect events developments.&#160; See Company&#146;s Form 8-K filing dated March 26, 1999, detailed statement forward statements.</font></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Item 1.&#160; DESCRIPTION BUSINESS</font></b></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">General</font></b></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Spherix Incorporated (the &#147;Company&#148; &#147;Registrant&#148;), Delaware corporation, founded 1967.&#160; The Company consists biotechnology segment (&#147;BioSpherix&#148;) information services segment (&#147;InfoSpherix&#148;).&#160; At May 2005 annual meeting shareholders approved establishment InfoSpherix wholly-owned subsidiary Spherix, effect January 2006.</font></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The principal executive offices Company located 12051 Indian Creek Court, Beltsville, Maryland 20705, telephone number (301) 419-3900.&#160; The Company&#146;s Common Stock trades NASDAQ Global Market system symbol SPEX.</font></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Available Information</font></b></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Our principal Internet address <u>www.spherix.com</u>.&#160; We make free charge <u>www.spherix.com</u> annual, quarterly current reports, amendments reports, practicable electronically file material with, furnish to, Securities Exchange Commission (&#147;SEC&#148;).</font></p> <p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">BioSpherix</font></b></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">This division Company&#146;s biotechnology research development arm, dedicated developing proprietary products view commercial applications.&#160; The Company accumulated number patents products processes developed BioSpherix.&#160; As set below, products development stage require substantial additional investment bring products market.</font></p> <p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Tagatose Low-Calorie, Full-Bulk Sweetener.</font></u>&#160; Spherix patented naturally occurring sugar, tagatose, low-calorie, full-bulk sweetener.&#160; It true sugar looks, feels, tastes table sugar.&#160; The Company developed patented method making tagatose whey lactose.&#160; Whey waste product cheese manufacturing.</p> <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">2</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center"> <!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='2',FILE='C:\fc\137231418693_D11556_2133429\14680-1-ca.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='May 17 23:14 2007' --> <br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Firm developing sweetener receiving U.S. patent manufacture low-calorie sweetener 1988, patent expired August 29, 2006.&#160; The Company received U.S. patents tagatose production process 1991 1992, expire July 19, 2009.&#160; It received number foreign patents U.S. patents.&#160; These countries include Canada Japan, large potential markets.</font></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In January 1997, Company completed license agreement Arla Foods Ingredients amba (&#147;Arla&#148;) (formerly MD Foods Ingredients amba, &#147;MDFI&#148;) exclusive, worldwide rights market distribute tagatose food beverage ingredient return non-refundable up-front payment fees net sales sugar purposes.&#160; Arla manufactures wide variety dairy products, foods food ingredients; ranks largest dairy products manufacturers world.&#160; Arla operates cheese plants producing large amounts whey by-product.&#160; The License Agreement amendment thereto provide Arla world-wide manufacture sell tagatose food uses, manufacture tagatose uses.</font></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">A panel experts retained Arla declared tagatose Generally Recognized As Safe (&#147;GRAS&#148;) April 11, 2001, permitting sale tagatose food ingredient U.S.&#160; The U.S. Food Drug Administration (&#147;FDA&#148;) issued &#147;no objection&#148; letter October 25, 2001.&#160; Tagatose recommended Joint FAO/WHO Expert Committee Food Additives (JECFA) panel June 2001 member countries foods, June 2004, JECFA removed limit daily consumption tagatose.&#160; In 2003, approval obtained South Korea.&#160; In April 2004, tagatose approved Food Standards Australia New Zealand (&#147;FSANZ&#148;), food health safety agency Australia New Zealand.&#160; In December 2005, tagatose approved European Union.&#160; Arla begun approval process tagatose Canada, Mexico.</font></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The U.S. FDA approved Arla&#146;s recommended caloric 1.5 kilocalories gram, permitting labeling products &#147;reduced calorie&#148; U.S.</font></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In 2002, Arla formed 50/50 joint venture Nordzucker, German sugar producer, manufacture sale tagatose.&#160; The joint venture factory capable producing 1,200 metric tons year.&#160; At present Arla believes produced sufficient backlog inventory satisfy foreseeable future based current demand, stopped production pilot plant sufficient increase demand tagatose.&#160; limited $350,000.&#160; For share common stock purchased SEDA, Cornell pay 95% lowest volume weighted average price (&#147;VWAP&#148;) shares trading days draw notice Cornell.&#160; The VWAP calculation reported Bloomberg, LLC, third-party reporting service.&#160; In general, VWAP represents sum sales common stock day (the total shares sold trade times sales price share common stock trade), divided total number shares sold day.&#160; We committed pay Cornell amount equal 5% purchase common stock made Cornell SEDA.&#160; Under terms SEDA agreement, obligated draw SEDA facility, satisfy normal conditions type transaction, require Cornell purchase common shares SEDA.&#160; In connection SEDA, issued Cornell 95,000 shares common stock paid due diligence fee $5,000.&#160; We paid Yorkville Advisors Management, LLC, investment manager Cornell, structuring fee $15,000, sale SEDA pay additional structuring fee $500.&#160; Newbridge Securities Corporation acted placement agent SEDA, paid firm fee 5,000 shares common stock compensation valued approximately $10,000.&#160; We granted Newbridge Securities Corporation piggy-back registration rights covering shares.&#160; Registration common shares allocated facility completed October 2005.&#160; During term SEDA, Officers Directors agreed sell shares common stock, extent permitted Rule 144.&#160; The number shares common stock issuable Cornell SEDA subject 9.99% cap beneficial ownership Cornell affiliates time sale (beneficial ownership calculated accordance Section 13(d) Exchange Act).&#160; Further, issue style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Spherix Incorporated<br> Notes Financial Statements</font></b><a style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">1.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; Summary Significant Accounting Policies</font></b></p> <h1 style="font-weight:normal;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:auto;text-indent:36.0pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Nature Business</font></i></b></h1> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On January 1, 2006, Spherix Incorporated transferred assets information services segment (the &#147;InfoSpherix Division&#148;) wholly-owned subsidiary, InfoSpherix Incorporated (&#147;InfoSpherix&#148;).&#160; Spherix Incorporated (&#147;Spherix&#148;) founded 1967, Companies incorporated Delaware.&#160; The activities biotechnology segment (&#147;BioSpherix&#148;) continue operate Spherix Incorporated.&#160; BioSpherix dedicated research, development, productization proprietary products.&#160; InfoSpherix operates contact center services providing consulting, information management, materials management public reservation tourism solutions.&#160; These services provided primarily government contracts.&#160; The Company maintains facilities Maryland, including corporate headquarters Beltsville, facility Indiana.</font></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Basis Presentation</font></i></b></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Beginning January 1, 2006, consolidated financial statements include accounts Spherix Incorporated InfoSpherix Incorporated (collectively, &#147;Company&#148;).&#160; All intercompany balances transactions eliminated.</font></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Use Estimates Assumptions</font></i></b></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The accompanying consolidated financial statements prepared conformity accounting principles generally accepted United States America.&#160; This requires management make estimates assumptions affect reported amounts assets liabilities disclosures contingent assets liabilities date financial statements, reported amounts revenue expenses period.&#160; Accordingly, actual results differ estimates assumptions.</font></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Cash Equivalents</font></i></b></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company considers highly liquid investments original maturities months cash equivalents.&#160; At December 31, 2006, Company approximately $6.5 million invested treasury funds maturity months less, included cash cash equivalents.&#160; The Company maintains cash balances banks.&#160; Accounts institution insured Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation $100,000.&#160; At December 31, 2006, Company&#146;s cash cash equivalent excess FDIC limits $10,751,000.</font></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Concentrations</font></i></b></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">During 2006, revenue major government contracts accounted 16%, 15%, 11% Company&#146;s total revenue.&#160; No contracts greater 10%.&#160; At December 31, 2006, major contracts constituted 68% trade accounts receivable, components 26%, 16%, 15% 11%.&#160; No single contract greater 10% total trade accounts receivable.&#160; Receivables Federal state government agencies represented 83% total trade accounts receivable.</font></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">During 2005, revenue major government contracts accounted 17%, 16%, 12%, 12% Company&#146;s total revenue.&#160; No contracts greater 10%.&#160; At December 31, 2005, major contracts constituted 75% trade accounts receivable, components 30%, 16%, 15% 14%.&#160; No single contract greater 10% total trade accounts receivable.&#160; Receivables Federal state government agencies represented 91% total trade accounts receivable.&#160; Government contracts accounted approximately 99%, 100%, 99% InfoSpherix revenue 2006, 2005, 2004, respectively.</font></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Property Equipment Depreciation</font></i></b></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Property equipment stated cost consist office furniture equipment, computer hardware software, leasehold improvements, capital leases.&#160; Computer hardware software include cost internally developed software programs, long-term benefits.&#160; The Company developed continues develop large variety software applications performance multiple contact center park reservation contracts.&#160; These applications designed aid telephone operators providing information public collecting caller information.&#160; The Company developed software applications to</font></p> <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Deferred Rent</font></i></b></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company entered leases Beltsville, Cumberland, Annapolis Indianapolis facilities 1997, 2003, 2004, 2006, respectively.&#160; The excess rent expense cash payments rent recorded deferred rent amortized life leases.</font></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Research Development Costs</font></i></b></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Research development costs charged operations incurred.</font></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Patent Costs</font></i></b></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Legal costs incurred connection patent applications costs acquiring patents capitalized incurred.&#160; When patents granted, costs amortized term representing lesser life patent projected sales period product process.</font></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Revenue Recognition</font></i></b></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Revenue recognized methods depending terms contracts:&#160; time materials fixed price.&#160; Revenue time materials contracts recognized contractually agreed-upon rates based direct labor hours expended direct costs incurred.&#160; Revenue fixed-price contracts recognized unit-of-delivery methods.&#160; Losses, any, contracts recorded period determined.</font></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Direct Contract Operating Costs</font></i></b></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s direct contract operating costs consist primarily labor fringe costs contact center personnel, subcontractors, telephone related costs, depreciation computer hardware software related facilities costs.</font></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Selling, General Administrative Expense</font></i></b></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s selling, general administrative expenses consist primarily executive management salaries fringes, sales marketing costs, finance accounting, human resources, general corporate costs costs related public company.</font></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Income Taxes</font></i></b></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Deferred income taxes recognized tax consequences future years differences tax bases assets liabilities financial reporting amounts year end, based enacted tax laws and</font></p> <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" based periodic assessments made management reduce deferred tax assets amount expected realized.&#160; Income tax expense tax payable period change period deferred tax assets liabilities.</font></p> <p accounts payable, bank line credit reported Consolidated Balance Sheet, approximate carrying short maturities.</font></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Accounting Stock-Based Compensation</font></i></b></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Effective January 1, 2006, Company adopted Statement Financial Accounting Standards No. 123(R) &#147;Share-Based Payment&#148; (FAS 123R), requires measurement employee share-based payments employees, including grants employee stock options, fair-value based method recording expense consolidated statements operations comprehensive loss.&#160; The Company Black-Scholes option pricing model elected modified prospective transition method and, therefore, restated results prior periods.&#160; At time Company adopted FAS 123R, unvested options outstanding.&#160; For year ended December 31, 2006, Company realized $24,000 stock based compensation expense relating 59,000 stock options awarded February 2006.&#160; The effect adopting FAS 123R increased loss operations, decreased income taxes net income $24,000 year ended December 31, 2006, effect basic diluted earnings share, net cash flow operations, net cash flow financing activities.</font></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">For years prior January 1, 2006, Company elected &#147;disclosure only&#148; presentation Statement Financial Accounting Standards No. 123 &#147;Accounting Stock Based Compensation&#148; (FAS 123) and, consequently, record compensation expense relating employee option grants provided exercise prices fair Company&#146;s common stock grant date.</font></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On November 4, 2005, Company total 176,658 previously unvested stock options outstanding.&#160; The exercise prices options greater fair Company&#146;s stock.&#160; On day, Board Directors voted fully vest outstanding stock options.&#160; The average weighted exercise price options $7.98.&#160; The primary purpose accelerated vesting enable Company avoid recognizing future compensation expense options adoption &#147;SFAS 123R.&#148;&#160; The related future stock-based employee compensation expense eliminated result acceleration vesting options approximately $562,000, effect increasing 2005 proforma loss $3,110,977 $3,672,738 proforma loss share $(0.26) $(0.31).</font></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">New Accounting Pronouncements</font></b></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" Taxes.&#148;&#160; We required adopt FIN 48 effective January 1, 2007.&#160;&#160; We evaluating impact interpretation financial position, results operations, cash flows.</font></p> <p &#147;Fair Value Measurements&#148; (&#147;SFAS 157&#148;).&#160; SFAS 157 defines fair value, establishes framework measuring fair, expands disclosures fair measurements.&#160; We required adopt SFAS 157 effective January 1, 2008. We expect adoption SFAS 157 material affect financial position, results operations cash flows.</font></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In September 2006, U.S. Securities Exchange Commission (&#147;SEC&#148;) issued Staff Accounting Bulletin No. 108 (&#147;SAB 108&#148;).&#160; SAB 108 addresses diversity practice quantifying financial statement misstatements potential current practice build improper amounts balance sheet.&#160; The bulletin requires companies quantify misstatements based impact financial statements related disclosures.&#160; We adopted SAB 108 connection preparation financial statements year ended December 31, 2006.&#160; The adoption SAB 108 material impact financial position, results operations cash flows.</font></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">6.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; Debt</font></b></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Line Credit</font></i></b></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">As result creation InfoSpherix wholly-owned subsidiary, management longer considers maintaining bank line credit parent company, Spherix, necessary, and, decided renew credit agreement matured March 31, 2006.&#160; The Company entered agreement March 31, 2006 Bank America (&#147;the Bank&#148;) establish line-of-credit (&#147;New Agreement&#148;) subsidiary, InfoSpherix Incorporated, outstanding borrowings approximately $1.5 million line credit transferred agreement.&#160; Management considers establishment credit facility subsidiary ensure timely cash flow subsidiary&#146;s operations.&#160; The New Agreement, matures June 30, 2008, borrowings $1.5 million, collateralized subsidiary&#146;s accounts receivables equipment, covenants tangible net worth funded debt EBITDA ratios.&#160; Such covenants limiting effect amount cash subsidiary advance Spherix.&#160; The interest rate Agreement based LIBOR daily floating rate 3% (approximately 8.34% December 31, 2006).&#160; The Company outstanding borrowings Agreement December 31, 2006, total amount future advance subsidiary $1.5 million Agreement.</font></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p> <p listing requirement maintaining minimum $10,000,000 shareholders&#146; equity.&#160; NASDAQ gave Company September 1, 2005, correct situation, Company achieved quarter results.&#160; However, anticipation incurring losses due seasonal fluctuations InfoSpherix business segment occur fourth quarters year, Company entered Standby Equity Distribution Agreement (&#147;SEDA&#148;) Cornell Capital Partners, L.P. (&#147;Cornell&#148;) July 22, 2005.&#160; Under SEDA, Spherix require Cornell purchase $4,000,000 Company&#146;s common stock two-year period effective date, October 12, 2005, registration covering shares common stock sold Cornell.&#160; The SEDA establishes termed &#147;equity line credit&#148; &#147;equity draw-down facility.&#148;&#160; The $4,000,000 facility drawn installments, maximum amount draw limited $350,000.&#160; For share common stock purchased SEDA, Cornell pay 95% lowest volume weighted average price (&#147;VWAP&#148;) Company&#146;s shares trading days Company&#146;s draw notice Cornell.&#160; The VWAP calculation reported Bloomberg, LLC, third-party reporting service.&#160; In general, VWAP represents sum sales common stock day (the total shares sold trade times sales price share common stock trade), divided total number shares sold day.&#160; The Company committed pay Cornell amount equal 5% purchase common stock made Cornell SEDA.&#160; Under terms SEDA agreement, Company obligated draw SEDA facility, satisfy normal conditions type transaction, require Cornell purchase common stock.&#160; In connection SEDA, issued Cornell 95,000 shares common stock paid due diligence fee $5,000.&#160; We paid Yorkville Advisors Management, LLC, investment manager Cornell, structuring fee $15,000, sale SEDA pay additional structuring fee $500.&#160; Newbridge Securities Corporation acted placement agent SEDA, paid firm fee 5,000 shares common stock valued $10,000.&#160; We granted Newbridge Securities Corporation piggy-back registration rights covering shares.&#160; Registration common shares covered SEDA completed October 2005.&#160; During term SEDA, Officers Directors agreed sell shares common stock, extent permitted Rule 144.&#160; The number shares common stock issuable Cornell SEDA subject 9.99% cap beneficial ownership Cornell affiliates time installment (beneficial ownership calculated accordance Section 13(d) Exchange Act).&#160; Further, Company issue 19.99% outstanding shares SEDA shareholder approval received.&#160; Fees paid cash common stock Cornell, Yorkville Advisors, Newbridge Security totaling $220,000 charged proceeds initial draw facility.&#160; In 2006, Company sold 819,453 shares SEDA agreement total proceeds $1,897,000, 2005, Company sold 310,076 shares SEDA agreement total proceeds $376,000.&#160; At December 31, 2006, Company&#146;s shareholder&#146;s equity $14.6 million.</font></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION</font></b></p> <p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Compensation Discussion Analysis</font></b></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Objectives Compensation Program What Our Compensation Program Designed Reward</font></b></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Our executive compensation program designed create strong financial incentive officers increase revenue, profit, operating efficiency returns, expect lead increase shareholder value.&#160; In addition, strive promote ownership mentality key leadership Board Directors.&#160; Finally, endeavor ensure compensation program perceived fundamentally fair stakeholders.</font></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Compensation Committee Board Directors (the &#147;Committee&#148;) evaluates performance compensation ensure Company maintains ability attract retain superior employees key positions compensation provided key employees remains competitive relative compensation paid similarly situated executives companies.&#160; To end, Committee believes executive compensation packages provided Company executives, including named executive officers, include cash stock-based components reward performance measured established goals.</font></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Our compensation program designed reward employee&#146;s contribution Company.&#160; In measuring named executive officers&#146; contribution Company, Committee considers numerous factors including Company&#146;s growth financial performance.</font></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Throughout Form 10-K, individual served Company&#146;s Chief Executive Officer Chief Financial Officer 2006, individuals included Summary Compensation Table page 46, referred &#147;named executive officers&#148;.&#160; Immediately Compensation Discussion Analysis find series tables specific information compensation earned 2006 named executive officers.</font></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Roles Responsibilities Our Compensation Program</font></b></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Role Compensation Committee</font></i></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Committee responsibility establishing, implementing monitoring adherence Company&#146;s compensation philosophy.</font></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Role Chief Executive Officer</font></i></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Our Chief Executive Officer recommendations Committee evaluation executive officers, including recommendations individual cash equity compensation levels executive officers.&#160; Mr. Levin relies personal experience serving capacity Chief Executive Officer respect evaluating contribution executive officers publicly information comparable compensation guidance basis recommendations Committee.&#160; provision services referenced compatible maintaining Grant Thornton&#146;s independence. The Audit Committee&#146;s policy pre-approve audit permissible non-audit services provided independent auditors.&#160; These services include audit services, audit-related services, tax services services.&#160; Pre-approval generally provided year.&#160; The Audit Committee pre-approve services case-by-case basis.</font></p> <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font
